Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Electron Acceleration and Emissions from the Solar Flare Termination Shock
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project plans to make significant progress toward our understanding of one of the key problems in solar physics; i.e., the question of how electrons are accelerated within solar flares. Solar flares are the strongest explosions in the Solar System, and they provide sites for particle acceleration and high-energy emission. However, the question of exactly how this acceleration occurs remains unsolved. The project will combine two powerful numerical models that will enable the principal investigators (PIs) to simulate the physics over a wide range of scales from the large scale flares that produce shock waves down to the smallest scales where the particle acceleration occurs. This project will also support the training of the next generation of solar scientists. The PIs will involve both undergraduate and graduate students in the research, and funding is provided for a postdoctoral researcher for the project.

In solar flares, a termination shock can develop when a high-speed outflow from the flare encounters magnetic loops in the solar atmosphere forming a standing shock wave that can accelerate particles to high energies. These shock waves had been predicted but never observed until recent X-ray and radio observations by one of the PIs (Chen). Motivated by this recent discovery, this project plans to investigate the dynamical evolution of termination shocks and their acceleration of electrons by combining, for the first time, two powerful numerical simulations: (1) large-scale magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) models of the dynamical evolution of a flare and (2) particle-in-cell kinetic and test-particle simulations for electron acceleration at the shock front. From the combined numerical model the PIs plan to generate synthetic hard X-ray emission and compare this emission with observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative project is to understand electron acceleration and emission by the reconnection-driven termination shocks (TSs) in solar flares. Solar flares are strong sources of energetic charged particles and radiations over the entire electromagnetic spectrum. The release of magnetic energy by magnetic reconnection is believed to be the driver of the entire process.  A standing TS can develop when the high-speed reconnection outflow encounters the reconnected post-flare loops and accelerates particles to high energy. The project investigates the dynamical evolution of the TS and its electron acceleration through several devoted studies including magnetohydrodynamic simulations of the dynamical evolution of the TS, particle acceleration modeling for electrons at the shock front, and generation of spatiotemporal synthetic hard X-ray emission from the numerical simulations and comparing them with observations. The project has led to important advances in all aspects of the proposed research.

Our magnetohydrodynamic studies have carried out one of the most sophisticated and comprehensive studies on the properties and dynamical evolution of TSs underneath a reconnection layer filled with a plasmoid chain. We have shown that plasmoids are produced intermittently in the reconnection current sheets and interact dynamically with the TS. The TS evolves dynamically and exhibits complex structures due to the impacts of plasmoids. We also demonstrate that the simulations reveal a dynamical feature consistent with radio spectroscopic imaging observations. Using a newly developed MHD-energetic-particle model, we have shown, for the first time, a shock-in-a-magnetic-trap structure for efficient particle acceleration and confinement of energetic particles, providing a natural explanation to the loop-top nonthermal sources. Importantly, this may be closely related to the “magnetic bottle” structure with a local minimal magnetic field and filled with energetic electrons, discovered in the Sep. 10, 2017 event by EVOSA and other observatories. As plasmoids interact with the shock, the looptop region exhibits various compressible structures that modulate the production of energetic electrons. The energetic electron population varies rapidly in both time and space.

The project has deepened our understanding of the fundamental physics of shocks, nonthermal particles, and radiation not only in solar flares but also in a broad range of solar and astrophysical environments such as gamma-ray bursts, pulsar wind nebulae, and black hole jets. The advanced probe and modeling of solar flare termination shocks have led to multiple session discussions in SHINE, AGU, and other meetings.
